explanation: Agent A is correct. The call to memcmp(nn->nonce, new_nonce, new_nonce_len) may read new_nonce_len bytes from both nn->nonce and new_nonce. The function only contains mhd_assert() checks to constrain new_nonce_len; asserts are typically removable (e.g. NDEBUG) and therefore do not provide the unconditional runtime guarantee required by MISRA Rule 21.17. There is no unconditional check that new_nonce_len <= sizeof(nn->nonce) nor any enforcement that the object pointed to by new_nonce is at least new_nonce_len bytes long. Although the provided execution log shows safe values at runtime, that does not eliminate the potential for out-of-bounds access in other executions. To comply with Rule 21.17, an unconditional runtime check (or a stronger interface contract enforced by the type/size) is required before calling memcmp.
